The outer layer our star pictured in red will contain helium molecules. Due to being a type 1b supernova, N132D’s progenitor star ‘loses’ its hydrogen shell during this red supergiant phase, possibly due to stellar winds (Yoon et. al 2018). There are 3 ways for hydrogen to be converted into helium, called the proton-proton chain or pp chain (Stellar Evolution and Nucleosynthesis Ryan et. al 2010 p. 24).
